text:
Green Lantern is a film that had so much potential but collapsed under the weight of excessive CGI and uneven execution. Ryan Reynolds, while a talented actor, struggles to balance the comedic energy that makes him great as Deadpool with the gravitas needed for Hal Jordan. The result is a performance that sometimes veers into unintentional parody, making it hard to take the character seriously in what was meant to be a heroic, epic narrative.

Blake Lively is serviceable in her role—charming and attractive—but her character doesn’t have much substance to latch onto. The film’s reliance on CGI-heavy visuals overshadows any genuine character development or storytelling. Scenes that could have carried emotional weight or tension instead feel sterile and artificial, leaving the audience disengaged.

The screenplay is a major downfall. The story is muddled, pacing is off, and dialogue often fails to land. With so much green screen and digital effects dominating the film, the narrative becomes almost impossible to follow at times. Critical story beats get lost in the spectacle, and what could have been thrilling moments are reduced to visual noise.

Director Martin Campbell seems overwhelmed by the visual demands, unable to balance the CGI spectacle with coherent storytelling. This results in a film that’s more exhausting to watch than entertaining, as the focus on effects comes at the expense of character depth and meaningful plot progression.

The only redeeming aspect of Green Lantern is the off-screen chemistry that developed between Reynolds and Lively, which became a talking point for audiences but does little to redeem the film itself. Otherwise, there’s very little in terms of enjoyment, excitement, or lasting impact.

Ultimately, Green Lantern is a cautionary tale of how over-reliance on CGI, combined with a weak screenplay and uneven performances, can sink a potentially great superhero film. It’s a movie best forgotten—watch it only if you’re curious, but don’t expect anything close to a classic superhero experience.
I liked it when I saw it in theaters as a kid, but wow, this was painfully boring.
I'd rather try to eat a live unrestrained lion with a plastic spoon from a toddler's birthday party than watch this film that wasted thousands of years of evolution to give us these writers

Ah the infamous Green Lantern, the punching bag of the internet and Ryan Reynolds (often in Deadpool form). It's a fun movie with its share of cheesy moments. The film gets a bad rap but I find it a bit underrated. It's certainly not going to win any awards but I found it fairly enjoyable. It has that campy early 2010s vibe that is endearing. Watching Green Lantern is like steeping into a time capsule. Its flaws, like the dated CGI and corny dialogue, gives it a certain kind of charm that makes it interesting to look back on. It was a different type of era for comic book movies that I have a lot of nostalgia for, despite the shortcomings. Definitely a step above several other comic book films with similar ratings.
Was there a plot. From what I can tell Ryan Reynolds took some kool aid and dreamed he was a bland superhero in a paper thin plot. Really uninteresting stuff. Watched on DVD.

Completely awful one of the worst films ever created 

Its AWFUL
One of the worst films I’ve ever seen. Horrible CGI which looked awful before the film even came out. Watch it if you like wasting 2 hours of your life.
La verdad no entiendo el odio extremo hacia la cinta, si es bastante entretenida aunque si algo mala a decir verdad
The worst green lantern movie that I seen.
Although I don’t think it’s nearly as bad as everyone say it is, the movie falls short due to terrible CGI and corny dialogue.

It had good qualities, some laughs, and a really weird villain. I like it. I’ve watched it multiple times. I’m watching as I write this (it’s on HBO). Also, technically it was a moderate financial success. They just didn’t too much money and messed themselves up. They should’ve gone cheap for the first one, marketed and THEN did a bigger budget film for the sequel.
I know that green lantern suit is CGI

I enjoyed it. Well directed by Campbell and well written. Stellar cast more than capable of convincing performances. Great cinematography and GCI, lots of action and enough twists to keep it interesting. This movie gets a lot of negative attention for trivial reasons, it's a MOVIE! Not the star in the DC universe, granted, but good enough

It's ok, but not a good movie if you realize the valle of GL in comics. And if they wanted to start a cinematic universe was a bad choice. If we think in Marvel, if this movie was the 24th between 50, no one would cares at all (like Shang Chi o Eternals, movies that no one really cares but didn't harm Marvel at all)
GARBAGE, the WORST superhero movie I have ever seen, Ryan Reynolds tried to make this a ok movie with the script he has, but overall this movie is no more than a messy slop
This is an OK movie.
Acceptable, nothing more.

I liked this movie. I think the worst thing about it was Ryan Reynolds being silly amd acting likemhimselfmornthe coolest effing guy that waits tables at shenanigans or goes to Coolidge College for too long. But the story was great and the visuals were amazing, i wish we had gotten a sequel.

its not as bad as its rated. i think it's a little bit tonally jarring for the introduction to the character. later mcu villains ensure a decent peppering of jokes and a long lead up, this movie just dives straight into an emotional climax that maybe should have been in the sequel or later. i guess we arent getting this character back unless it's as a joke though.
